newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Bosnian war crimes suspect ill in hospital.
newsitem.headline: Bosnian war crimes suspect ill in hospital.

text.p: The U.N. tribunal for the former Yugoslavia said on Tuesday a war crimes suspect held in in the Hague after his arrest in Bosnia last week, needed "several days' monitoring" in a prison hospital.

Bosnian Serb Milan Kovacevic was arrested by British forces on Thursday last week as part of "Operation Tango", a crackdown on indicted war criminals still living in the Prijedor region of northwestern Bosnia.
He was flown to the tribunal's detention cells in the Hague the same day.

Kovacevic underwent a medical after his arrival in the Hague during which "the doctor discovered the existence of pathological problems which call for the accused to be placed under supervision," the tribunal said in a statement.
A tribunal spokeswoman said she had no further details of Kovacevic's condition other than that the problem was of a physical rather than mental nature.
The hospitalisation would mean a date for his initial appearance before the U.N. war crimes court would not be set before early next week, the tribunal added.

Another suspect targeted by "Operation Tango", Simo Drljaca, was shot dead by British soldiers as they tried to arrest him. Drljaca, the notorious hard-line former police chief of Prijedor has since been buried and honoured as a fallen hero.
Both men had not known they were the subject of secret tribunal indictments.

The Prijedor purge was one of the worst crimes against civilians in Bosnia's war. Serbs led a brutal ethnic cleansing campaign in the early stages of the 1992-1995 war, herding Moslems and Croats into detention camps, where they tortured, beaten, and in some cases, executed.
Dusan Tadic, the first Bosnian Serb to be tried by the Hague-based tribunal for war crimes, was sentenced to 20 years in prison on Monday for his part in atrocities in Prijedor.
